awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Realtime Atmospheric Mapping and Monitoring System to Enable a Next-Generation Global Navigation Service
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve Position, Navigation, and Timing infrastructure.  Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) are used to provide mapping capabilities in billions of devices annually, but an estimated 140 million have critical needs for high security and/or accuracy.  Furthermore, future cyber-physical systems, such as self-driving cars and aerial mobility, will have higher performance requirements, including safety-critical operation, precision positioning, and cyber-security for billions of devices. This project will advance a new positioning system. 

This SBIR Phase I project proposes the development of a space-based Atmospheric Mapping and Satellite Integrity Monitoring system (AMSIM) to support a high-integrity, precise positioning service from a Low Earth Orbiting (LEO) satellite navigation constellation. This requires monitoring satellites for faults and mapping ionospheric and tropospheric conditions, traditionally accomplished via a network of ground infrastructure, such as the Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS). However, to achieve the precision needed for autonomous systems, ground monitoring stations must be spaced less than 100 km apart, limiting performance over oceans and other remote areas. This work proposes the investigation of a space-based monitoring approach for a ubiquitous service. It will leverage inter-satellite communication links for integrity monitoring, techniques in GNSS Radio Occultation (RO) for tropospheric monitoring, and tomography for ionospheric mapping. This Phase I project will use physical models, computer simulation, and available atmospheric data products derived from RO and ground-based monitoring approaches for validation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our critical infrastructure, transportation systems, and day-to-day lives critically depend on Position, Navigation, and Timing (PNT). Today, this vital service is provided by satellite navigation systems in Medium Earth Orbit (MEO) with satellite constellations like the U.S. GPS, European Galileo, Russian Glonass, and Chinese BeiDou. These represent marvels of engineering as well as immense undertakings by nation-states designed to support government needs. Today, commercial systems demand higher levels of performance from legacy PNT systems while becoming more critically dependent on them.  Intelligent transportation systems like self-driving cars are one of many applications pushing PNT demands and with it the need for modernized infrastructure to support their deployment at scale.

We present a novel concept for a commercial New Space approach to commercial satellite navigation, one architected to meet the PNT needs of demanding applications, including autonomous vehicles. This concept leverages the ecosystem which has enabled the Mega Constellations of the likes of SpaceX and OneWeb. These factors combine orders of magnitude in cost reduction in access to space along with new techniques in high volume satellite production. Xona’s commercial PNT constellation, Pulsar, is designed for Low Earth Orbit (LEO) to utilize Mega Constellation satellite buses, components, and launch systems intended for that regime.

To achieve the required PNT performance and reliability, we introduce a distributed architecture which leverages an interconnected and lightweight space segment. In this NSF Phase I effort, we evaluated the space-based monitoring elements of the Xona Pulsar LEO PNT system. Known as the Atmospheric Mapping and Satellite Integrity Monitoring System (AMSIM), this examined feasibility of the approach and identified the correct path forward towards commercialization. This included atmospheric monitoring for both enhanced precision as well as integrity monitoring for the detection of satellite faults. Combined, these elements form the basis for a commercially viable, precision navigation service from LEO to support future demands of critical PNT users.

A simulation tool was built from the ground up to evaluate the performance of AMSIM. In atmospheric monitoring, results showed that the proposed Xona Pulsar constellation provides the observability through Radio Occultation techniques to create tropospheric refractive corrections for use in precise localization. Combined with the rapid geometry change of fast-moving LEO satellites, this showed convergence times to centimeter position levels that are comparable to other industry standard methods based on differential GPS but without the requirement for dense ground monitoring networks. An integrity monitoring scheme was developed that leverages measurements between neighboring satellites that showed feasibility towards achieving aviation-levels of safety. 

This NSF Phase I effort informed several key design decisions of the Xona Pulsar service where a demonstration satellite mission will be flown next year to collect data and further test concepts developed here as another step towards commercial deployment and meeting growing industry PNT needs.
